<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 123, 637, 146]]<|/det|> # Cambridge International AS & A Level <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 185]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 220, 165, 235]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 213, 424, 259]]<|/det|>
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[891, 221, 919, 238]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 722, 248]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[728, 213, 905, 257]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[724, 221, 904, 238]]<|/det|> <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 277, 231, 292]]<|/det|> # MATHEMATICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[827, 279, 905, 294]]<|/det|> 9790/53 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 302, 338, 317]]<|/det|> Paper 5 Probability & Statistics 1 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[759, 302, 907, 317]]<|/det|> May/June 2025 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[759, 326, 905, 341]]<|/det|> 1 hour 15 minutes <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 395, 371]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 391, 400]]<|/det|> You will need: List of formulae (MF19) <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 225, 432]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 291, 450]]<|/det|> - Answer all questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 449, 761, 466]]<|/det|> - Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 808, 481]]<|/det|> - Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 481, 565, 497]]<|/det|> - Write your answer to each question in the space provided. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 497, 482, 512]]<|/det|> - Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 361, 528]]<|/det|> - Do not write on any bar codes. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 867, 545]]<|/det|> - If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 482, 575]]<|/det|> - You should use a calculator where appropriate. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 881, 591]]<|/det|> - You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 605, 854, 620]]<|/det|> - Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question. <|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 669, 214, 680]]<|/det|> # INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 683, 388, 698]]<|/det|> - The total mark for this paper is 50 . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 730, 715]]<|/det|> - The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 74, 446, 91]]<|/det|>
1 For a set of 40 values of \(x\), it is found that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[321, 101, 678, 122]]<|/det|>
\[
\sum(x-k)=836.0, \quad \sum(x-k)^{2}=25410.8
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 136, 289, 151]]<|/det|>
where \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 166, 682, 183]]<|/det|>
(a) Given that the mean of these 40 values is 124.0 , find the value of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 443, 555, 462]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the standard deviation of these 40 values of \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
2 At a large college, all students who study Science also study exactly one of Art or Drama or Music. \(20 \%\) of these students study Art, \(45 \%\) study Drama and \(35 \%\) study Music.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 121, 708, 138]]<|/det|>
(a) 3 students are selected at random from the students who study Science.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 152, 675, 168]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that at least 1 of these students studies Drama.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 460, 719, 477]]<|/det|>
(b) 10 students are selected at random from the students who study Science.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 492, 601, 506]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that more than 7 study Art or Music.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
3 A fair six-sided dice with faces labelled \(1,2,3,4,5,6\) is thrown repeatedly until a 3 is obtained. The number of throws taken is denoted by the random variable \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 121, 277, 138]]<|/det|>
(a) Find \(\mathrm{P}(X=8)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 306, 280, 323]]<|/det|>
(b) Find \(\mathrm{P}(X<9)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 552, 783, 569]]<|/det|>
(c) Find the probability that a 3 is obtained for the second time before the 6th throw.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
484 people attempt a particular puzzle. The times taken, in minutes, to complete the puzzle are recorded. These times are represented in the cumulative frequency graph below.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[178, 134, 825, 520]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 556, 918, 573]]<|/det|>
(a) Use the graph to estimate how many people took between 4 and 7.5 minutes to complete the puzzle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
(b) On the grid below, draw a box-and-whisker plot to summarise the information in the cumulative frequency graph.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 117, 790, 324]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 631, 91]]<|/det|>
5 Bag \(A\) contains 6 red marbles, 5 blue marbles and 1 green marble.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 105, 504, 122]]<|/det|>
Bag \(B\) contains 5 red marbles and 3 blue marbles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 136, 606, 152]]<|/det|>
A marble is chosen at random from bag \(A\) and placed in bag \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 168, 487, 182]]<|/det|>
A marble is now chosen at random from bag \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 198, 846, 214]]<|/det|>
(a) Draw a tree diagram to represent this information, giving the probability on each branch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 671, 91]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the probability that both marbles chosen are the same colour.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 443, 918, 463]]<|/det|>
(c) Find the probability that the marble chosen from bag \(A\) is blue, given that the marble chosen from bag \(B\) is blue.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
6 A company sells bags of pasta. The masses of large bags of pasta are normally distributed with mean 2.50 kg and standard deviation 0.12 kg .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 119, 918, 138]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the probability that the mass of pasta in a randomly chosen large bag is less than 2.65 kg . [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 419, 581, 436]]<|/det|>
A restaurant manager buys 160 of these large bags of pasta.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 449, 918, 466]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the number of bags for which you would expect the mass of pasta to be more than 1.65 standard deviations above the mean.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 76, 918, 92]]<|/det|>
The masses of small bags of pasta sold by the company are normally distributed with mean \(\mu \mathrm{kg}\) and standard deviation \(\sigma \mathrm{kg}\) ．Tests show that \(77 \%\) of these bags have masses greater than 1.26 kg ，and \(44 \%\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 107, 355, 122]]<|/det|>
have masses less than 1.35 kg ．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 136, 584, 153]]<|/det|>
（c）Find，in either order，the value of \(\mu\) and the value of \(\sigma\) ．

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 901, 91]]<|/det|>
7 A set of friends consists of 7 men and 4 women. Three of the men are brothers: Ali, Ben and Charlie.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 105, 918, 122]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the number of different arrangements of the 7 men in a line in which Ali and Ben do not stand next to each other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 459, 918, 477]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the number of different arrangements of the 7 men and 4 women in a line in which all the men stand together and all the women stand together.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
(c) In how many ways can the 7 men and 4 women be divided into a group of 6, a group of 3 and a group of 2 if there are no restrictions?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 427, 898, 446]]<|/det|>
(d) The 7 men and 4 women are divided at random into a group of 6, a group of 3 and a group of 2 .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 459, 711, 477]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that Ali, Ben and Charlie are all in the same group.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 105, 918, 122]]<|/det|>
If you use the following page to complete the answer to any question, the question number must be clearly shown.
